Dear Ms. Oberlin:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
08/01/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Tyler Armstrong, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee’s performance
within 30 days of the completion of the probationary
period or within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee’s performance
annually thereafter.
2

One of three current employee files reviewed did not have a timely employee
evaluation completed annually.

The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was offered regarding receiving consent from parents of youth
placed, considering the sudden nature of which placements can occur.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
previous year’s renewal inspection resulted in an approved Corrective Action Plan
dated 07/20/2023. Action steps were put in place to address information received
at intake for youth, documentation of discharge elements reviewed with youth and
families, and required tasks completed prior to hire of new employees. All
previously cited rules did not result in violations during this inspection.
Financial Overview
Yearly budgeting and financial overviews were provided, and no concerns were
noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
3

Chief Administrator Assessment
The annual assessment by the Chief Administrator was received and dated
08/09/2024. In it the Chief Administrator reviewed the Corrective Action Plan from
the previous year's inspection and did not note any difficulties in following action
steps and eliminating concerns that resulted in previous findings.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed stated they enjoyed working in the facility and helping the youth
they serve.
The current youth placed reported she felt safe and cared for in the facility, and was
excited to take advantage of new independent living programming and housing
upon discharged offered by the agency.
Description of Agency Walk Through
No safety concerns were noted within the building. Cleaning products and
medications were stored safely. The facility houses several different programs for
youth and adults including the CCI license. Youth utilize a common cafeteria and
recreational space that is sufficient for their needs.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
